items.title: Claude Opus 4 and 4.1 can now end a rare subset of conversations

items.summary: How to close the loop between user behavior and LLM performance, and why human-in-the-loop systems are still essential in the age of gen AI.

items.title: The Download: Taiwan’s silicon shield, and ChatGPT’s personality misstep
items.summary: This is today’s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Taiwan’s “silicon shield” could be weakening Taiwanese politics increasingly revolves around one crucial question: Will China invade? China’s ruling party has wanted to seize Taiwan for more than half a century. But in…

items.title: Decoding Palantir, the Most Mysterious Company in Silicon Valley
items.summary: This week on Uncanny Valley, we talk about one of the most notorious American corporations. So what does Palantir actually do?

items.title: Developers Say GPT-5 Is a Mixed Bag
items.summary: Software engineers are finding that OpenAI’s new GPT-5 model is helping them think through coding problems—but isn’t much better at actual coding.

items.title: Why GPT-4o’s sudden shutdown left people grieving
items.summary: June had no idea that GPT-5 was coming. The Norwegian student was enjoying a late-night writing session last Thursday when her ChatGPT collaborator started acting strange. “It started forgetting everything, and it wrote really badly,” she says. “It was like a robot.” June, who asked that we use only her first name for privacy reasons,…

items.title: Indigenous knowledge meets artificial intelligence
items.summary: There is no word for art in most Native American languages. Instead, the closest terms speak not to objecthood but to action and intention. In Lakota, “wówačhiŋtȟaŋka” implies deep thought or reflection, while “wóčhekiye” suggests offering or prayer. Art is not separate from life; it is ceremony, instruction, design. Like architecture or code, it carries…
